awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Antarctic Surface Hydrology and Future Ice-shelf Stability
awd_abstract_narration:
Ice shelves are the floating portions of glaciers that terminate in the ocean.  They are common around the periphery of Antarctica.  The accumulation of surface meltwater on or near the surface of ice shelves can play a role in ice-shelf collapse, which leads to accelerated loss of grounded ice and sea-level rise. Recent studies have showed that present-day meltwater generation and movement across the surface of Antarctica is more widespread than previously thought and is expected to increase.  Consequently, there is a growing need to address the role of surface water in forecasts of ice-shelf behavior. While much progress has been made, understanding of the role of water in ice-shelf collapse is still in its infancy. This award supports a workshop that will bring together experts from multiple disciplines that, together, can advance understanding of Antarctic surface hydrology and its role in the future stability of ice shelves.  

This workshop will bring together U.S. and international scientists with expertise in ice-sheet dynamics, glacial hydrology, climatology, and other disciplines to identify critical knowledge gaps and move the community towards answering fundamental questions such as: What climate dynamics are responsible for surface meltwater generation in Antarctica? What controls the spatiotemporal distribution of meltwater ponds on Antarctic ice shelves? Where is meltwater generated, where does it pond today, and how will this change this century? How will meltwater impact ice shelves? How will surface hydrology impact sea-level this century?  The deliberations will be captured in a workshop report and review paper that will be broadly distributed.

por.por_cntn:
It has been known for decades that in some isolated parts of the Antarctic Ice Sheet, the surface of the ice and snow gets warm enough to melt. There is evidence that the resulting surface meltwater can cause areas of the ice sheet to flow faster, which accelerates sea-level rise. Understanding the multitude of processes that link surface melting to the flow of the ice is critical for improving projections of future sea level rise.  


Nearly 70% of the Antarctic Ice Sheet flows through, thick, floating ice shelves that form the boundary between the ice sheet and the surrounding ocean. Surface meltwater can cause the ice sheet to lose ice by impacting the stability of these ice shelves. This was dramatically demonstrated in 2002 when the Rhode Island-sized Larsen B Ice Shelf, which had been in place for thousands of years, collapsed over a period of a few weeks, following intense melting. The theory is that meltwater caused the collapse by flowing down into cracks in the ice and, because water is denser than ice, enlarging the cracks, causing the ice shelf to break apart. The ice shelves are floating, so when they break apart they do not significantly affect sea level. However, while they remain intact ice shelves act to slow the flow of upstream land-based ice. When ice shelves collapse, observations have shown that the land-based ice starts to flow faster and is partially lost into the ocean. This causes the sea level to rise more quickly.


Recently, climate models have predicted that surface melting will increase this century and that more ice shelves may become vulnerable to the effects of meltwater. The advent of new satellite and field observations has built on previous research to show that meltwater already forms on many ice shelves around Antarctica, generating large stream networks and feeding large lakes.


Understanding how surface meltwater impacts the rate at which the ice sheet losses mass into the ocean is a complex scientific problem, involving studies of climate, hydrology and ice-shelf flow and fracturing. Many research groups across the country and internationally are researching different aspects of this issue and we recognized that bringing these researchers together would help the scientific community focus on addressing key questions related to Antarctica’s future contributions to sea-level rise.


In February 2018 we hosted a workshop on Antarctic Surface Hydrology and Future Ice-shelf Stability at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Palisades, New York. The aims of the workshop were to (1) establish the state-of-the-science of Antarctic surface hydrology, (2) identify key science questions, and (3) move the community towards answering these questions, by bringing together scientists with diverse expertise. Funding for the workshop was provided by the U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) Antarctic Glaciology Program. Attendees included 47 scientists from a range of career stages and one artist. We had a gender balance among the 18 science talks.


Many exciting new findings were presented at the workshop. What became clear is that meltwater is moving around on the surface of Antarctica in many ways that we do not yet fully understand. Meltwater is formed around the edge of the continent in very specific places that we cannot fully explain, and when it flows into cracks on ice shelves, we do not currently know how to reliably predict whether or not this will cause the ice shelf to collapse.

The field of Antarctic surface hydrology is growing and early results are exciting, but fundamental questions remain unanswered: What controls where melting occurs? Where does the meltwater water go? How does it affect ice shelves?

A major outcome of the workshop was identifying priorities for future research:

  • Understanding the varied causes of meltwater production and its distribution across Antarctica.

  • Determining the fate of Antarctic surface meltwater.   

  • Improving how climate models describe melting, hydrology and ice-shelf fracture.

These are major challenges that must be addressed in order to predict how meltwater will impact the future stability of the Antarctic Ice Sheet.

The first step towards this goal is to prioritize studies aimed at improving our understanding of the processes involved. These should include targeted field observations, such as meteorological observations in melt-prone areas, ice-core records of melt, and direct observations of fracturing and meltwater flow.

A second outcome of the workshop a simple new approach for framing future research in this field, based around identifying (1) where meltwater accumulates, (2) where meltwater matters for ice-shelf stability and (3) where ice-shelf stability matters for sea-level rise. For more details, including a full workshop report, visit www.antarcticsurfacehydrology.org.
